I totally endorse his private member's bill on holding people responsible, should we have to close the gate after the horse has bolted.

Because of the seriousness of the johne's situation in my electorate, I have been forced to help create a support network. I have endeavoured to find the extent of the problem. I have got a survey going out in the electorate at the moment, and beyond the electorate, into the Mudgee area and beyond, to find out the extent of the johne's problem. Several studs have already been commercially crippled by their johne's status. There is one stud of three generations which is now virtually unable to do anything with its stock except cut the wool off it and sell the stock for mutton at vastly reduced prices.

One Mudgee producer told me the other day that he bought rams from a quarantined stud in 1989 and, with no testing of his stock, he has now been placed under a similar quarantine. At the end of the day, two years down the track after the current task force program has undertaken to try and look at the problem, he may come out of it as clean as a whistle, but with that suspicion over him he is commercially devastated at the moment. His lucrative commercial market for wethers is now a loss situation as he tries to sell his cast‐offs as mutton. I also suspect that johne's could have an impact on our mutton exports. We should be very wary that, if there is any suspicion of a link between johne's and any possible human contamination, there is a real risk that we may find another market threatened.

I believe that these people need urgent exceptional circumstance assistance on an ongoing basis while the task force conducts its two‐year study into this. I am also in the throes of seeking a specialist counsellor because there are people who are close to being suicidal over the impact that this disease has had on their enterprises. It has the potential to devastate our merino industry if we do not attack it very soon as a matter of national importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool International Amendment Bill 1996 is a very important piece of legislation for one of Australia's great industries, one that I might add is under very considerable pressure, and one in which I think some people have not realised the ongoing effects that occur when we see such a decline in the profitability of the wool industry, particularly where it affects specialist growers who become totally unviable.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also another effect which is becoming noticeable in an electorate such as O'Connor, where you have a very substantial mixed farming operation and within that mixed farming each part lives off the other. It is often forgotten that proper rotational aspects of grain growing require a grazing industry and an industry where we rely on those leguminous pastures to reinvigorate the soil during that process. What is happening at the moment is that, due to quite good grain prices and disastrous wool prices, we are seeing wall‐to‐wall grain growing and a consequent decline in the protein levels of the grain produced. What has always been a problem in my electorate at the best of times is being aggravated by a reduction in the balance between grain growing and wool production. These are the sorts of side issues that get neglected when one tries to focus on the direct problem.

The legislation takes a relatively simple step in reducing the requirement for fixed release from the stockpile, from 182,000 bales per quarter to 135,000 bales per quarter until 30 June 1997, and then 90,000 bales thereafter. Conversely, and I think probably unwisely, we also see the maximum allowable go out to 350,000 bales, which basically says, `Release is now again open slather.'

I remind the House that, whilst that was a consensus decision taken by all sectors of the industry, in terms of the confidence factor it has totally removed it again. We moved on Garnaut's recommendation to fix release in a very narrow range of minimum and maximum because, as he pointed out, the previous arrangement did not let the industry, at the buying end, know the quantities that were coming out of the stockpile and that they could not budget for it when they went to buy fresh wool.

I have reminded this House of the most significant words that I have heard in this debate. They were made by a wool trader who said at a meeting that I attended that he did not care how expensive wool got but he was deeply concerned at what his competitor paid for it tomorrow. The fundamental of this issue is that, if those sitting in an auction room bidding for fresh wool have no idea of what is going on at Wool International, they take out insurance by paying less. That will continue and we will have people keeping their own stockholdings down to the lowest possible minimum, with the intention of making sure that they do not get caught again.

This problem will not be resolved by having such a wide differential between the minimum to be sold and the maximum, unless there are some very clear declarations made in advance as to the intentions of Wool International in that regard. It is all about certainty and, whilst we recognise the problems relating to demand, I think certainty or the lack of it has been the real issue into the steady decline of prices in the wool industry.

I think the movement of prices downwards, after the announcement of this arrangement, further adds to that problem. I am not totally happy with the move but, on the other hand, I support it as an improvement and as something that was achieved by a consensus arrangement between all aspects of the industry. Unless, as a consequence, Wool International, in the marketing of its own stockpile, improves the transparency of its negotiations, I do not think confidence will return by this measure. To me, transparency means everybody knowing Wool International's forward price, before a particular quarter commences.

I draw attention to the fact that there were similar concerns in the wheat industry when the Wheat Board entered into the domestic markets in a big way. It was doing deals and making private sales out of its own stockpiles, which we refer to as `the pools'. People got very concerned about the integrity of that process and, I think, with good judgment. We had the situation where the domestic trading arm and the WIF were making magnificent profits. And, of course, it is easy to make profits when you are buying from yourself. We had a transfer from the revenues of the pools to the revenues of domestic trading and WIF investors. I do not want to go too far down their track but their solution was to start calling forward tenders so that the market became transparent. They went as far as to appoint KPMG Peat Marwick to open the tenders so that not even their own operation had access to those tenders.

It appears to me that it would be a practical approach for Wool International to nominate its disposal for the forthcoming quarter and to consequently call tenders on the basis that—this is always common in such tendering—anybody who did not bother to participate in the tender but wished to purchase wool at the level set by the tender process could only do so at a premium. That means that you could not sit back and let one of your colleagues be the sole tenderer and then you benefit from that depleted price.

If there was a true tender process—as I said, in one quarter for wool of the next quarter—that was subject to the condition of no tender necessarily accepted, as with the Wheat Board, I think we would see the prices get into the marketplace early. This would help buyers, particularly those with this very flexible arrangement of 90,000 to 350,000. It would also give Wool International the opportunity to state its intentions very clearly. It would put a floor in the fresh wool market so that people could go in and bid, knowing that they did not have someone else—one of their competitors—on the telephone doing a deal with Wool International into the forward market.

I have corresponded with Mr Richardson on this matter and he says, `Our activities are transparent.' If he means that they do a deal and then announce it, yes, it is transparent to that extent. But that is no help to you if you are in the open auction system bidding for fresh wool while the telephone conversations are going on; you do not know what they are up to. So I think we could progress this forward and I think there is opportunity to follow down the road of the AWB tender system—with variations, no doubt. It is something that would give genuine transparency and give people a clear indication as to where they stood. This system would be much more positive were that to be included. I do not think it requires legislation—it would just become the selling policy of Wool International.

The other aspect of all of this—and other members have referred to it—is that demand for textiles and quality clothing is down internationally and, being a provider of product to the higher end of the market, we have seen a disproportionate effect on wool. We have been contributors to promotion through the International Wool Secretariat for as long as I can remember. Unfortunately, the method by which we raise funds for that is inversely proportional to the need. In other words, the lower the sales the lower the amount of money we have to promote sales, and the higher the sales the larger amount of money we have to promote sales. That is an inverse ratio.

Everyone will tell you that when life gets tough, you have to expand your promotion to try and lift the market. Yet we have a system that reduces the amount of money at that time. Whilst I am totally opposed to the concept of Wool International investing in a marketing proposal called Wool International Holdings—I have no support for their proposals there at all—as a wool grower I am quite happy to see some of my investment in Wool International used in this downturn for positive promotion.

But I want to add a concept to that promotion. We have just heard the previous speaker, the member for Calare (Mr Andren), worrying about whether cotton is getting ahead of wool or, for that matter, whether synthetics are getting ahead of wool. I have always wondered why we had to keep wool as an unique product when there were great market opportunities in blends. But, putting that aside, the issue really is about getting people back to wearing some decent clothes, convincing them that their discretionary income should go in that direction. We have to get the models and the film stars and, I might add, we have to get the schoolteachers to come to school looking as though they appreciate the clothes they wear.

I have just come back from the Melbourne Cup, where we had an argument about what people should be wearing on that day. But, let me tell you, if they all wore morning suits it would sell a hell of a lot of wool. The reality is that we have to convince the world that this scruffy approach is not good enough. We have to get the basketballers back into some trim gear and we have to encourage women to dress up a little more to go to the supermarket. That is something we should do together—the cotton industry, the synthetics industry and the wool industry.

When you think of our gross advertising budget, what we put into wool promotion is minuscule. If the three industries together put 10 per cent of our total marketing into just making people more aware and more keen to dress up, instead of spending it at the casino or wherever else they spend it today, then I do not think the wool industry would have any problems with its percentage share of the market. I think you grow the market and we have got to get our bit. Of course, as we convince people through all of those things that one should also be seen in a superior product, then hopefully our market share would grow with it.

We should still direct a substantial part of our advertising budget to the special attributes of wool clothing and wool textiles. But the reality is we want some growth in the textile market. I hope by this speech I can encourage those who are directly involved to go out and say to our competitors, `Let's get together on the issue of improving the actual demand for textiles.' It is low and partly that is because people have, by any standard, become very scruffy.

BREAK.PARA: One only has to look at the century‐old advertisements for the AFL to see how people dressed when they went to the football 100 years ago: there were rows and rows of three‐piece suits and hats. Of course, that has changed and it has made it a lot more difficult for our industry. As one of the positives, whilst we try and patch up the problems of supply, when we look at demand we have got to look past promoting wool. There are all these arguments about whether we should promote only Australian wool and, okay, there is a component for that. But, generally, we want people around the world to dress better and to be more conscious of the clothing they wear, and there are promotional activities, of course, that can do that.

In the last couple of minutes, I just want to come back to my arguments about Wool International Holdings, which is all part of this particular program. There is simply no reason to invest wool growers' money in an aspect of marketing when the industry, as established, can do all of those things. If Wool International Holdings has got some super whiz ideas and if they have got some computer people or others who can provide us with better mechanisms for selling wool, then let them make them available to the industry as a whole. If they have spent a little of my money on it, that is fine. But there is no reason for them to sequester $24 million of wool growers' reserves to go out there to keep themselves in a job, and that is what it is all about—when they are finished selling the stockpile, they are finished. It is up to competitive industry to get out there and to market wool better and to convince growers that that is the best way to go.

Advertisements appear regularly in papers in my electorate telling people, `Send your wool to us' and giving seven different ways in which they will sell it for them. If there is an eighth way that is better, let that private concern add it to its list. But I am deeply concerned to see that the two largest private concerns now want to make an agreement with Wool International Holdings and come forward and say, `We'll do it better, but we'll also control 70 per cent of the market.' That is terrifying. Wool is not grain; wool is in many categories. Wool is a different product, and people are entitled to a system that represents that issue. I sell wool every year and I bet that, if I bothered to go back, I would probably find that the same buyer buys it every year. He is comfortable with it and he knows what I produce. It is not all that special but, on the other hand, he knows it and he would buy it because of that. Once I am put into some massive system, whatever advantage I have achieved for myself over those years is lost.

These are some of the points I want to make and I really want to stress two points. The first one is transparency in the disposal of the stockpile—genuine forward transparency. If there is to be a forward market, there has got to be forward transparency. The second point is that I would like to think that we had the sort of change to our international promotional activities that I have outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool International Amendment Bill 1996 should be called the `half Bourbon' bill: it has learnt nothing, and it has forgotten everything. It really does not add anything, in my view, to the wool industry. You do need transparency in the market. That transparency can only be achieved by selling all the wool on the auction market without reserve, and that is how it should have been disposed of. But that does not provide jobs for Wool International in the long term.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember going to Dubbo when the Garnaut report was released. The Garnaut report was a very flawed document, as one would expect from the author of the Australia and the Northeast Asian Ascendancy report. I remember going and addressing a crowd at Dubbo and expressing my concerns about the shortcomings of his proposals. The now Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) got up and read—in his well‐articulated, nice, school‐rounded vowels—great tracts from the Garnaut report. At morning tea, a fellow said to me, `By jove, we're lucky to have a bright young fellow like John Anderson up there in parliament, representing us!' I felt then that they were about to get the government they deserved. John Anderson sat at his round table, and who did he have at the round table? All the same people who have been going round and round for years. There was nothing new there and there was nothing new that could come out of it.

It is quite clear that what we are doing here is simply adding to the likelihood of a Wool International dynasty; an organisation which, I believe, should be swept away at the very first opportunity. We have heard people here today talk about various aspects of wool marketing. It is my view that wool marketing is not the concern of wool growers; it is the concern of people who make the end product—they are better at it.

I finished wool classing in South Australia in, I think, 1956. When we got our certificates the director said to us, `Every one of you will now go out and overclass the clip,' which every one of us did and still do. He said, `And if you want a future in 25 years, you have to address the American market; you have to raise the percentage of wool used in the American market.'

We spent $2 billion worth of growers' money doing that and we have achieved nothing. The level of wool use is about the same as it was. On the other hand, Zegna went into North America; it sent Jonathon Todhunter into North America with a month's wages and after that he was on his own. North America is now one of Zegna's biggest markets. They had success. When you look at how we attempted to market wool in America, $2 billion is an awful lot of money to growers but it is infinitesimal over that period in terms of television advertising. It was a silly concept and it failed because it was silly.

I believe that the generic marketing of wool should be swept away; it is a nonsense. What the Australian wool grower is doing is promoting everybody else's wool. We are not in the wool business, we are in the merino business and it is that which we need to promote. I recall going to China on one occasion. The delegation asked whether we could actually go to a shop where the Chinese shopped and I was amazed at the volume of stuff that was being sold out of this fifth floor: very high prices with a big banner saying `Bespoke tailoring, only the finest British cloth used.'

I said to the young lady, `Do you have any Australian woollen jumpers?' `Oh no, sir,' she said, `we stock only the finest British wool.' So I asked to have a look at a Pringle jumper. I said, `Look, there you are: it says guaranteed pure botany wool.' She said, `No, no, no. Look, made in England.' You could not convince her that it was Australian wool.

Pringle did not use the woolmark because they realised that everybody else used it and there was no value in it; there was no status in it. All you have to do to use woolmark is produce hair off a sheep. That has been very detrimental to the Australian wool grower. I believe we should be promoting Australian wool; and not necessarily Australian wool but we should have competing brands within Australia so that at the end of the day what is sold is Australian.

Wool is a tremendously important industry—unlike the tourist industry, it actually contributes greatly to rural Australia. It is probably the biggest small business in Australia. I believe that it is being very badly treated. We hear talk about wool's market share. The member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) spoke about a buyer who said that he did not care what the price was. That is an absurd statement. It is quite clear that wool is price sensitive, particularly in the band where most sold wool occurs, the 20 to 24 micron range.

The minute it goes above a certain point, Marks and Spencer's computers start to tick away and they change their blend so there is less wool and more synthetic. When you consider that they are selling a suit somewhere in the world every 30 seconds, it is a very important factor. Wool is price sensitive: the traditional ratio has been about three to one on cotton. When it gets over that, there is downward pressure on its use; when it is under that, use tends to be pushed up.

That is for the great bulk of our wool; that 20 to 24 micron range. If you look at commodity prices throughout the world, since about 1974 commodity prices have been trending downwards. This means that wool producers are going to be under continuing cost pressure and this has to be addressed. How do you address this? Do you address it by having Wool International Holdings aligned with the two biggest wool brokers in Australia? I think not. What has to happen is that wool growers have to hold on to that product till further down the production chain.

But this could only happen in a totally free market and if wool growers could organise themselves to hold on to their product down to the yarn stage—you will notice that in recent times when there have been dramatic drops in the price of even tops, when tops have been selling below cost, the price of yarn has not altered much—and if we could organise the sale of yarn by areas. A friend of mine has just registered `Nullarbor' as a brand name because he believes there will be a change in Europe. Europe is still the trendsetter—not China, not Japan—in wool design, and he thinks there will be a move towards sports coats. Twenty‐four micron wool is ideal for sports coats. He believes that there is a substantial industry there supplying 24 micron wool guaranteed environmentally friendly—no pollutants at all. And that is one thing Australia has to offer—that clean, green image.

The member for Calare (Mr Andren) mentioned ovine johne's disease. It is a disgrace that it was not stamped out when it arrived here from New Zealand but it was ignored and allowed to spread. It should be stamped out now and the people affected by it should be compensated by the government because it was the fault of the government. We see AQIS moving to the rational economic field and there are people in AQIS who actually believe that we will all be better off, that the playing field will be truly level, when we all have the same diseases. I believe this is a national disgrace and it has been ignored by all major parties.

The member for O'Connor mentioned Wool International Holdings and he objects very strongly to its operation. I know there are very many members of the government—both in the National Party and the Liberal Party—who did not support that bill. But, like the member for O'Connor, they all voted for it and I think that is a disservice to the people they are purporting to represent.

The member for Calare mentioned making more use of Australian wool. Quite clearly, it is better if we can get Australian wool used in blanket production for hospitals. I was in Esperance recently and I tend to fossick around army disposal stores, and I came on some wool singlets made for the army in 1948. I bought a heap of them. They are extremely comfortable and surprisingly good for hot climates. Worn next to the skin, there is no trouble at all, and that is army gear of 1948. I suspect it was made of probably nothing less than 20 micron wool but certainly it is quite comfortable on the skin. So technology existed then for this material. Yet the last time I went to a Kangaroo exercise—I think it was Kangaroo `92—the soldiers were complaining about their polyester shirts and how uncomfortable they were in the tropics. The shirts made life almost unbearable for them; you could see the sweat pouring off them. If the army had experimented with a wool‐cotton mixture, perhaps a wool‐cotton polyester, it would have provided our soldiers with a much better garment. Certainly I believe that our serving people should have the very best equipment and cost is not a real consideration in that exercise, because the additional cost is actually quite minuscule.

In terms of the wool industry, you have to get some meat back on the bones. The wool industry has suffered enormously in recent times and a lot of this, in my view, has been self-inflicted because the wool industry has left representation to its so-called peak bodies and I do not believe they have represented the industry well. They have left it very much to government.

It is not the occasional low price that devastates the industry. It is the years and years of declining prices; of prices just above the cost of production. If you actually graph the price of wool since wool has been marketed, probably 150 years, wool has gone through 700c—in 1988 dollar terms—2½ times every 10 years except for that period when it was interfered with by the so-called organised marketing. I think that that is going to be coming under increasing pressure as commodity prices slide. As I said, the only way to improve this is to move further down the production chain.

We have made moves in that direction and I want it on the record that the Austops plant in Parkes—which the member for the area, Michael Cobb, supported very strongly, as did I—is a big success. It is the only top maker in Australia whose order books are full on a 24‐hour production run for at least six months ahead. It is doing very well. That facility was actually achieved under enormous opposition from elements in the wool industry. The attacks on Mr Todhunter, the man whose idea it was, were appalling. I think it is a disgrace the way he was treated and certainly a blight on the previous Attorney‐General, Michael Lavarch. I am glad that it was resolved very much in Mr Todhunter's favour.

What we see in this bill is better than existed before. It is a little late—we should have had these changes before, when wool was at very low prices and we were still allowing Wool International to sell forward at lower prices than the closing prices on the auction market. Wool International's argument was, `Oh, but we sold at a premium in a rising market. You would expect us to sell at a loss in a falling market.' That is nonsense. Anyone can sell at a premium in a rising market. What marketing is about is maintaining your advantage. It is quite clear that if you sell forward at a lower price than your closing price, then the opening price for your next auction is going to be lower. That is just simple, elementary, primary school economics. I fail to see how governments and the genii of Wool International could not understand this.

What I am saying is that this schedule will be much better if they are forced to sell it on the open market without reserve. That is the only way you are going to get transparency into it. What is important is not to make a profit on the wool stockpile, not to balance the books for the convenience of government, but to put meat back on the bones of the wool producer. And that is not, in my view, going to be achieved by this. I think we will see a rise in wool in the new year and that will certainly be most welcome. But unless we address the fundamental underlying problems, it will be another cyclical rise. And welcome as that will be, it will not be something on which you can built the future or the confidence of the industry.

BREAK.PARA: I was interested to hear the attack on merino stud breeders by the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur). I have always seen the member for Corangamite as the hero, the doyen, of the merino stud breeders. I remember when I was lobbying to get the export of Australian genetic material banned, the member for Corangamite was one of the people standing up and saying, `Oh no, we can't do this.' He was acting at the behest of those second‐rung or second‐grade merino breeders who thought they could make a quick quid out of exporting their merino product without any consideration for the long term effect on the industry.

In my endeavours to stop the export of Australian genetic material and genetic technology, I had the support of all the major studs. It was only a small element of the merino stud breeders that opposed it. Australia has been lucky in the past because our main customers have been communist countries and, through their incompetence, they wasted the opportunity they had. Instead of centralising the breeding stations, as we kept telling them to do, they tended very foolishly to put them out as rewards to good communes. The genetic material was therefore lost.

I think the threat in the future is going to be from South America. It will be driven by the Italians—and the Italians simply will not make that mistake. With the new technology, 900 rams a year might as well be nine million—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make a couple more points in this rather disjointed process. In the dying days of Bob Hawke's prime ministership, he had a look at the proposal to put the wool stockpile into what was called zero coupon bonds. He had his experts look at it and they determined that, in the rising market, it was highly feasible and they undertook to do that. Unfortunately, within a few days he had lost to Keating, who never had any interest at all in the wool industry. In my view, a great opportunity to get rid of the wool stockpile, and not have growers plagued with this enormous overhang in the market, was lost. It was an idea that clearly would have worked and it is a pity that it did not get support from the wool industry. I guess there were people in the wool industry who saw themselves being out of a job if the stockpile ceased to exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I join a long list of speakers this morning who have spoken in woollen suits, cotton shirts and synthetic ties. I welcome the introduction of this bill which sets new, overdue and more flexible parameters for the selling of stockpile wool. It is intended that the very last bale from the stockpile will be sold by 31 December 2000. Before that, the debt will be totally retired by 31 December 1998. Of course, in both instances, an earlier date is possible. The sales that do take place between the end of 1998 and the year 2000 will build up a surplus of dollars which will eventually be returned to the wool growers, as they largely determine, in one form or another.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to cast our minds back over what wool growers in this country have been through in the last half decade to decade. The stockpile has been in excess of 4.6 million bales. Today it is 2.04 million bales, according to the last figure I saw in the Land. So we have more than halved it and it has been a painful process. The debt has come down from $2.8 billion to something around $1 billion today. On that billion‐dollar debt there is a government guarantee, which means that the interest rate is lower than it would otherwise be. I do not know what that is, but it would probably be around seven or eight per cent.

BREAK.PARA: A lot of the wool now in the stockpile is old and matted. Some of it is triple dumped, it shows a certain amount of discolouring, and has to be discounted when it is sold—by something of the order of 25 to 30 cents a kilogram in some cases—because it has to be steamed and pulled apart. The composition of the stockpile is mainly over 21‐micron wool. When I looked in last week's Land, I think only two bales that had been sold for the week were less than 20.5 micron. So the great bulk of the wool is in the broader micron category.

With the fixed selling schedule under the Garnaut recommendations, which have been in place since 1993, we had to sell 187,000 bales a quarter—give or take 5,000 bales—which was a minimum of 728,000 a year. That is not an inconsiderable amount of wool as a percentage of total Australian sales. That was all very well, as previous speakers have said, on a stable or rising market. But it did run into somewhat unforeseen problems on a falling market, mainly in the psychological impact it had on the market when the market was coming down and you were trying to sell forward so that you were not caught trying to off‐load all your quarterly stockpile requirement at the end of the quarter.

It had to be discounted and, even if the discounting was done in a quite proper commercial way, the psychological effect on the market was very bearish indeed, particularly when you took into account the discounting that had to take place because of the age and matting qualities of the wool. If you were discounting even 20, 30 or 40 cents a kilogram, it had a quite depressing effect on the market—more than it otherwise should have. This meant that when the market rose the stockpile sales tended to clip that rise a bit, but when the market fell it accentuated the fall. Generally speaking, it has been a large contributor to the flat and falling markets that we have seen in recent years.

The minister, to his credit, has agreed that the minimum requirement should fall to 135,000 bales per quarter between January and the end of June next year, with a maximum of 350,000 bales. That is a lift in the upper limit. From 1 July next year until the last bale is sold the minimum will be 90,000 bales a quarter and the maximum 350,000 bales a quarter. In other words, the minimum is about half of what is applying now. That will be very welcome.

When that happens and the stockpile numbers get down, the other, more basic fundamentals—supply and demand—can come into play more. If you look at world wool supply, you will see that it is actually down on traditional volumes that have existed in the past. Australia is not producing much more than 600 million kilograms at the moment. In the heyday of a decade ago we were churning out from 700 million to over 1,000 million kilograms a year. So all the supply signals should be saying that the price of wool should be much higher than it is.

I believe demand will improve. Russian dumping has fallen away and as the world economy picks up, the secondary stockpile numbers fall and, in particular, the main stockpile numbers come down to a million bales or less, then I think we shall see a slow and steady increase in market price, which is good. When you connect that with the reasonably buoyant mutton and lamb prices that we have enjoyed in recent times, there are hopefully good days ahead again for wool growers in this country.

It is interesting to think about what you would have done with the stockpile, had it been your own private business. Let us look at what businesses would do when caught in such situations—not that I think too many businesses would be caught in such a diabolical situation as happened with the stockpile. Probably they would sell it all off in one year, if not less. They would have taken immense pain in the short term—more pain than we are experiencing now— but they would have cleared the problem away. If that had happened, we would probably now be selling fresh wool into a pure market situation, and that situation would be behind us.

That is a hypothetical situation, of course, because we cannot do that with something which is, in a sense, a public asset. Nevertheless, what we are doing is quite different from what we would be doing in private business. We should never forget that. It is an interesting thing that we should all reflect on from time to time. The moral of all that is the less government control and interference in any market situation the better.

There are some subtle changes mooted in this bill, apart from what I have spoken of, which concern the objectives of Wool International. The change is that, when determining the rate of disposal of the wool stockpile, Wool International will be required to take into account the profitability and efficiency of the Australian wool industry in the short, medium and long term. Until now, that consideration has only applied to the long term. It will now apply to short and medium term as well, which I think is perfectly logical.

In summary, I believe the changes are very sensible. They have been well accepted throughout all of the wool industry. The minister has done a great job in pulling the industry opinion together to recommend the changes in this bill. If you go to a meeting with some 100 growers there, there will be at least 101 opinions. A significant proportion of those opinions will change throughout the course of the meeting—not only change once but, in some cases, several times. It has been a nightmare trying to get some sort of consensus position within the industry. At the end of the day, I think the minister did a remarkable job.

I am pleased to see that, while some disagree with what has happened, there is across‐the‐industry support for it. Wool growers can now see the future more clearly. There are deadlines in place for clearing debt and clearing the stockpile. As I say, once the stockpile comes down below one million bales, the market can start rising again.

I will just make some quick general remarks pertinent to the wool industry and to this bill. I mentioned earlier that there has been immense pain for wool growers in this industry over the last few years. During that time, all elements of the industry have been unprofitable. It has put incredible stress on families.

As one who represents 40 per cent of New South Wales, including most of the western division and including many farming families who can do nothing else on their properties except grow wool, I have seen a lot of this hardship take place. It has also caused me great grief as a wool grower. Through that time, these families have also been through drought as well as on occasion having interest rates over 20 per cent, and so on.

The situation was brought home to me when I was in Bourke the other day at an opening of Centacare, which is a Roman Catholic‐run body—partly funded by the Commonwealth government—that assists people in financial and other troubles. It had been operating for a month before the opening and already many of the families that were on their books for counselling were farming families, going back several generations on the land, who had been forced off their properties in recent years through this wool crisis and were now living in the town of Bourke. Some of them might have chosen to move to coastal areas in their forced retirement, but they could not afford to do so. There they are living in Bourke. Some of the families have split up while others are staying together under great mental stress. I am pleased to see that organisations like Centacare are assisting these people.

I add that Sister Margaret Flynn, who has been a driving force behind Centacare in the central west of New South Wales, is based in Forbes and runs another Centacare office down there. It also has on its books, as a significant part of its clientele, farming families in trouble that have been through the recent recessionary periods.

On the price of wool, as I have said, it has been frustratingly low in recent years. Sales this year are significantly higher than last year—by 25 to 30 per cent in some instances. Overseas demand is flat and the price for the competitive fibres to wool—cotton and synthetics—are also reasonably flat. At the moment, the ratio of wool to cotton and synthetics is about 2½:1. So, traditionally, we can expect no more than perhaps a 20 per cent lift in the short term if that ratio is to be maintained. But if that happened, of course, the price of wool would lift from about 600c to 700c and at least that would lift it to a break‐even situation for a lot of growers.

There has been a great deal of soul searching in the wool industry in recent times over questions such as advertising of the International Wool Secretariat: should it be generic or brand, should it be pitched at the younger rather than the more mature consumer, should it concentrate on selling pure wool or blended wool, and so on. These are matters for debate which will go on.

Regarding the Woolmark—the famous Woolmark which is so well‐known around the world that we now charge for its use—I think 3,600‐odd companies have registered for it and that has brought in $16 million, which is badly needed, particularly in light of the fact that the previous government only a short time ago chopped off the last $20 million that they used to give us for wool promotion.

We also have in place, now it has been launched, the India 2005 strategy to get the domestic use of wool in India up and also their purchases of Australian wool, which they will process and re‐export. I think that is a welcome initiative. Indeed, the Deputy Prime Minister returns from India tomorrow, I think—if not tonight—and I look forward to hearing what he has to report on that particular initiative.

There has also been in recent times a different focus on wool blends. The wool plus lycra mix going into knitwear and woven wear is showing good signs of success and there are opportunities for an increased drive into value added blends which will open us up into new markets. In recent decades we have lost the young market; we have lost the casual market; we have lost the sporting market; we have lost the hospital blanket market; we have lost the working clothes market, and there have been changes in the work force of those who use wool. Airconditioning means that we use a lighter weight fabric and, with the build‐up in cotton and other fibres, wool is being hit from every angle.

It is worth remembering that wool has got only 20 per cent of the world apparel market even though Australia produces over 80 per cent of the world quality wool apparel market. We live in a dynamic and ever‐changing world and market. Long gone are the days of fixed prices, reserve schemes, regulating supplies, influencing demand in improper ways and so on. Ownership of a property and a mob of sheep certainly does not guarantee anybody a living income these days.

Finally, I would like to compliment one initiative of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) who has extended the drought exceptional circumstances assistance, after you are taken out of drought, from six months to 12 months. That is very welcome in my area and will allow many farming families that would have been taken off that assistance about Christmas time this year to continue it for another six months. All that will help keep wool growers on their farms, put food on their tables in the interim and, hopefully, with some good seasons and some rising prices, there is optimism again for the wool industry in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support the words of my good friend and colleague the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), who has outlined some very important challenges that face the wool industry. I join this debate as a wool grower and also as someone who represents one of the great wool growing areas in Australia. I am very proud to represent that area, but I have to say that it has certainly suffered over the last six years with some of the problems that the wool industry has been facing.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this bill, the Wool International Amendment Bill 1996, does go some way towards alleviating some of the immediate pressures that the wool industry is facing. What it does has been outlined, but it is worth repeating that the quarterly disposal mechanism for Wool International from the stockpile is to be altered as of 1 January to a minimum of 135,000 bales for each of the next two quarters, and then from 1 July next year it will lower to a minimum of 90,000 bales. As well as that, there will be an upper limit of 350,000 bales per quarter, and there is a target date of the end of 1998 for the debt of Wool International to be completely paid off. Also, there is another target date, the end of December 2000, to completely get rid of the stockpile.

Another very important and significant point about this legislation is that Wool International's charter will include a requirement that its sales objective be to improve the net return, not only for the stockpile wool but also for the whole wool industry in Australia. I think that is a very important aspect of this change. It is one that growers have been looking for, and it is certainly one that I believe, with the flexibility that is coming about through this new stockpile arrangement, will allow growers and Wool International the opportunity to look at how best to maximise the value for the industry in the coming years.

As has already been outlined, the industry certainly has been going through a very difficult period. I feel that by addressing this immediate problem of the stockpile disposal—and unfortunately this is not the first time that this has been addressed—we will allow the industry to really focus on what I see as the biggest challenge; that is, how to create additional demand for wool. There is no doubt that wool has had some difficulties over recent years, many of them brought about through factors beyond the control of the industry—for example, the collapse of the former Soviet Union and the recession in much of Western Europe in the early 1990s. The compounding of all these things has certainly, with the overhang of the stockpile, made it very difficult for the market to return to the sorts of prices that are desperately needed in order to make wool growing a profitable business again.

So, all in all, it has been a very difficult period. But from the work that the minister has put in at two very productive meetings of the round table when representatives of all areas of the wool industry came to Canberra, there was very strong agreement to proceed down this path with the wool stockpile management proposal that is in this legislation. It is also very heartening to know that the proposal has strong support right throughout the parliament. I believe that it will pass through fairly quickly, as expected, so those changes will be able to be implemented from 1 January, which of course is not very far away.

I say that the big challenge now is to increase demand. I think it is time that we put that challenge in perspective by looking at what a couple of other primary industries have been through. In both cases there were similar difficulties, and they have now come out much stronger. I am talking about the dairy industry and the wine industry. While there are many parallels, there are quite a few differences, but nonetheless I think it is illustrative to look at some of the figures that show what has been done with those two industries. I would like to quote a few statistics to show just what has happened. As everyone knows, it was only about 12 years ago that the dairy industry was on its knees, and yet today it is an industry that has pulled itself up to become a very successful exporter.

If we go back to 1970, the production of milk per farm was around 240,000 litres per year; by 1994‐95, the production per farm had nearly trebled to 610,000 litres; and this year it is estimated to be around 650,000 litres. Interestingly, from 1970 to 1994‐95 the production per cow increased by 37 per cent. In fact, I heard a researcher saying that in the last 25 years the potential has increased by significantly more than that; in some areas, the production per cow has literally doubled. More significantly, there is an expectation that the production will double again in the next 25 years. What I am saying is that there is a challenge for the wool industry to see what production improvements can be made on farm; I do not believe that the limit has been reached. We have opportunities to make some significant increases.

It is also significant to note the impact that the dairy industry has had on exports. While Australia produces just two per cent of the world milk production, it has 10 per cent of the world trade. Just 20 years ago, dairy exports were $250 million; today, they are in excess of $1.3 billion—of that, $1.2 billion actually comes from Victoria, so I am very much aware of the significance of the exports in a local way. That is an increase of 430 per cent. The dairy industry has achieved that not only by continuing to export what we might call the traditional products—dried milk powder, basic cheese and butter—but also by going into all sorts of value adding products. The increases in exports to some of the Asian countries have been truly staggering with an increase of at least 15 per cent per year being quite common.

It is interesting to note that if you go to the waterfront in Melbourne more than half the container exports out of Melbourne are dairy products. By this example I am attempting to show that here is an industry that took up the challenge. Dairy farmers were on their knees 12 years ago, but they took up the challenge and moved into exporting a whole lot of new products.

I also draw attention to the wine industry where, again, we see some very interesting similarities. In the mid‐1980s, there was a chronic oversupply of wine. Our exports were relatively small with an emphasis on premium varieties. What Australia has done in the wine industry has been to concentrate on value adding. Since 1966, wine production has actually tripled and, more significantly, the industry adds over $900 million to purchased inputs, which is seven times the farm gate value of what it has been producing.

Not only that, the wine industry has demonstrated that it can succeed overseas on quality—something that, as an analogy, I believe the wool industry is also very well placed to do. This success has led to higher margins and the Australian product is seen as quality wine. There is a push towards consumers trading up to quality wine, and the actual sales of bulk wines are declining. These are all significant factors. If you look at the industry's strategic plan, by the year 2025 it plans to achieve $4.5 billion in annual sales—a very significant figure. I point out that that is on a par with the total value of wool production.

The wool industry is very much at a crossroads. We have already seen a decline in the national sheep flock by a third; it is down to its lowest level for about 40 years. The challenge now is to take up this demand creating opportunity—while we still have some stockpile there—and turn the stockpile into an asset. The way to do that is to generate more demand and I believe that a number of very significant things will be happening down that track. For example, the IWS is now taking a much more forward approach to its marketing.

I am also very heartened to note that the IWS is likely to be subject to more accountability from the Wool Council, which is something that I happen to think is long overdue. I believe that these are the sorts of challenges and pressures that have to be placed on the marketing arm of the wool industry to really start to get some results.

I know that time is limited here: I could go on for much longer, but I will not. I would like to say again that I am very pleased to speak in support of the bill. I believe that it is a positive step forward in the management of the stockpile. The wool industry has indeed been through a very difficult period. However, there are still plenty of wool growers who are keen to see it recover and are working very hard to do so.

I hope that, through the opportunities that are going to come in the next few years, the wool industry will indeed become the premier primary industry in Australia again. I certainly believe it can do so. Looking at the way some of the other primary industries, such as dairying and the wine industry, have turned around after a very difficult period, I certainly believe that the opportunity, the challenge and the will are there. There is the chance to make it happen, and this legislation is the first step in setting it down on the path of recovery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter, Bob, Jnr, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, with the debate on the Wool International Amendment Bill 1996, we are strengthening, and continuing to hold on to, some ability to statutorily market the product wool, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) is making a very laudable effort to enable Australian wool producers to collectively market their product. To me, it would be absolutely ludicrous if we were to deregulate completely this industry. I do not know how many wool producers we have got. I heard quoted recently the figure—but I do not know whether it is correct—of 40,000 wool producers in Australia, each one of them individually marketing his product.

SPEECH.PARA: To think you can capably market a product worth—even in its present state of decline—$3,000 million a year to the Australian economy, by having little producers, who each produce maybe $300,000 or $400,000 worth of wool, individually selling their wool on the world market is, to me, a ludicrous proposition. Clearly, the giant commodity traders—such as Itoh, which is often quoted as having 30 per cent of the world's market for wool—will clap their hands together and cheer loudly because, in each of the international commodities that I am familiar with, it appears unassailably that you have what the economists call a classical oligopoly situation. For us humble, simple Cloncurry boys, that is explained to me to mean that a few people have a monopoly, and that there is a monopoly working out there which is owned and controlled by a very few players.

Look at the international beef industry—dominated by giants, such as Conagra—or at the banana industry, of which Chiquita had 80 per cent of the world trade at one stage, and not so very many years ago, either, I might add. Or look at the wool industry, where Itoh is such a giant buyer; or at the sugar industry—where E.F. Mann and Tate and Lyle make even CSR look small beer. Tate and Lyle quoted recently that they had 50 operations throughout the world, each the size of Bundaberg Sugar, and that figure would make them very considerably larger than the entire Australian industry put together. So, how in heaven's name is some little sugarcane farmer from outside Babinda going to compete against the might of a company that is something like four or five times the size of the entire Australian sugar industry put together? Clearly, he is not; clearly, he is going to be torn to pieces in the marketplace because of the enormous market powers that are in control.

So I want to praise the minister who has had a very difficult row to hoe in arriving at this position. Of all the industries in Australia, wool is, if not the worst, most certainly close to the worst in lack of direction and centrality in decision making. So making any sort of decision is extremely difficult; whichever way one is going to move, one is going to be criticised.

We have had people in this place—and I must say it is almost universal here—criticising the reserve price scheme, which absolutely amazes me. I have this terrible penchant for reading history books and people write down what occurred. The history books already read that prior to our securing the reserve price scheme, which was so brilliantly and courageously implemented by the then National Party leader, Doug Anthony, the auction price per kilogram for greasy wool was 64.7 cents. That was in 1970‐71. The year before it had been 82 cents, the year after it was 75 cents.

Within one year of the introduction of the reserve price scheme the price had leapt to 180 cents per kilogram—a 300 per cent increase. It is more than passing strange that when we introduced a reserve price scheme the price suddenly leapt 300 per cent. That was pure coincidence! Not only that, the reserve price scheme was able to maintain and to build up that price continuously from 1972 through to almost 1992. It was around 500 to 600 cents per kilogram in the late 1980s and at the end of the 1990 financial year.

Within one year of the demolition of the reserve price scheme, the price had fallen to 354 cents a kilogram from its high of 640 cents a kilogram in 1988‐89. So within 18 months of the removal of the reserve price scheme the price had collapsed straight through the floor. If any intelligent person wants to argue with me at any forum in Australia I am quite happy to do it, because no‐one in Australia who looks at that evidence is going to believe anything else but that if we introduce an aggressive statutory marketing arrangement that enables us to aggressively market our product, then we will achieve enormous results not only for that industry but for the Australian economy.

What the ALP did was that Mr Kerin undermined the confidence of the market in the price. In fairness to him it was said that it was foisted upon him by the Prime Minister. But I was a minister for many years and there were three occasions on which I had to tender my resignation because I could not live with the decision that was foisted upon me from above. On the third occasion, I did in fact resign. So I say that it is not good enough to say, as the then Minister Kerin said on numerous occasions behind closed doors, `I was forced to do it.'

The result to the Australian economy is that whereas our nation, which I would like to think we all love, was enjoying an income of $6,000 million a year from wool, we now enjoy an income of $3,000 million a year from wool. That is thanks to Mr Kerin and Mr Keating, and to other people on our side of the House who were in favour of the demolition of the reserve price scheme. Well, some of them may have voted for it but they may not have been happy about voting for it, in fairness to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were very happy to vote for it!
—Let me just take the interjection—
—I would rather you not take the interjection and just get on with the bill. We should not have any interjections.

—The point is that the confidence in the marketplace had been undermined completely. I have not got time to do the base research myself so I will quote from a speech by Senator Boswell in which he quoted his sources. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the week before Mr Kerin's infamous press conference in which he clearly indicated that the government was no longer going to stand behind the reserve price scheme we were buying only 20 per cent of the wool clip and the price was 890 cents a kilogram.

Two weeks after his press conference, the reserve price scheme had to buy 80 per cent of the trade and the price had slumped to the reserve price minimum of 870c a kilo. So you can say it was the removal of the reserve price scheme, but it was the clear‐cut neon light signal that was sent out by the minister, stating that the government was going to walk away from the reserve price scheme, which in any event was the level playing field of the economic rationalist policies of the Keating government. That was the basic locomotive of their decision making for 13 years and we are reaping the whirlwind now.

I put on record the price movements in the wool industry. There was a 300 per cent increase from 64c to 180c when we introduced the reserve price scheme and when we removed it there was a drop in the market from 640c down to 340c—it dropped clean in half.

That is not the full story of the damage. What has happened is that our sheep numbers have fallen some 40 per cent. I was corrected the other day when I said 30 per cent and they said 50 per cent. As far as I can see, there are a lot of different figures, but undoubtedly no‐one will argue that the sheep numbers in Australia have fallen by pretty close to 40 per cent. So we have lost our sheep now as well. Even if the price were to come back, there are not the sheep numbers there to produce the same revenue that would have existed had the price stayed where it was.

I can also refer, as far as statutory marketing goes, to the sugar industry. Before the then minister, John McEwen, called a world conference on sugar, sugar had slumped to $56 per tonne. After the international agreement was negotiated by John McEwen, even though he always said he was deeply regretful that it was never as good and never held as strongly as he wanted it to, the price leapt from a low of around $60 per tonne up to around $130 per tonne by 1973.

If there is anyone who doubts that we can achieve these sorts of results, in the Australian of 10 October 1994 there was an article by John McIlwraith on a 50 per cent aluminium price rise. He went into the detail of how the world's aluminium producers were called together for a conference where they decided to take 10 per cent of the world production of aluminium off the world market. The net result was that the market strengthened and we had a 50 per cent rise in the price of aluminium.

I refer to a Financial Review article dated 2 August 1993 which talks about the Brazilian government calling a conference of all the world's coffee producers. Coffee is a commodity very similar to wool in so far as there are probably only seven or eight countries in the world that are responsible for about 90 per cent of world production. They were called together by the Brazilian government and were successful in raising the price of coffee some 37 per cent over a four‐month period after the conference was called.
There are numerous articles here on OPEC, where their conferences have been successful in affecting the price of oil and we have been able to see—or suffer—a vast increase in the price of oil.

BREAK.PARA: Whatever commodity we are talking about, where we have aggressive marketing policies and where we are prepared to be intelligent enough to act collectively, we can achieve results. The previous speaker, the member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), outlined what had been done in the dairying industry and there is no doubt that what he said was 100 per cent correct. Those people have had the intelligence to realise the absolute necessity for unity. In Australia today, after 13 years of Labor government, we have seen the absolutely disastrous rise of Woolworths and Coles and Franklins in this country, to a point where there are now only three people that you can buy anything off and there are only three people that you can sell to. I might add that, as far as the workers of Australia are concerned, there are only three employers in the retail trade.

They have lifted their market share from around 60 per cent 10 or 15 years ago to where it is now at 74 per cent. There is no stopping it. With extended trading hours being introduced by various lackey governments throughout Australia, they will take an even bigger slice of the market. I tell you what, any of us politicians that want to assail them will not get much coverage in the media, because they are the biggest advertisers in Australia. You will not be getting too much coverage when you want to bring them to heel, and it will be a brave government that tries to stand against them.
But if you are a manufacturer, if you are a food producer in this country, you now have only three people that you can sell to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 11.52 a.m. to 12.11 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the division, I was talking about the absolute necessity for the collective marketing of our products. In spite of all that has transpired over the last 13 years, the labour market in Australia is collectively bargained. I believe that that is a very good thing. I have always believed that the right of the trade union movement and workers throughout Australia to collectively bargain is an important part of any properly functioning democracy.

BREAK.PARA: The medical profession is cutting off completely the supply of doctors into Australia. It is using its muscle power to ensure that no degree from anywhere else in the world will be recognised in Australia and that people from overseas countries will not be allowed to practise in Australia. In Queensland, the doctors have demanded that a person has a degree before being allowed into medical school, so that has cut off the supply of doctors there for three or four years. The medical profession is very effectively collectively bargaining its product.

Unfortunately, the level playing field is being forced upon the rural producers of Australia. It seems to me that only the manufacturing sector and the farming sector are being put to the sword. If we are not allowed to collectively bargain our products, the international commodity brokers who dominate the world marketplaces will tear us to pieces.

I have been to a number of wool meetings in which the so‐called leadership of the industry has said that it is amazing that, even when the flow of wool onto the market is cut back dramatically, nothing has any influence upon the price. Getting back to the economists again, they have a name for that, and it is this big word that I did not understand called `oligopoly'. That is the name for a market mechanism that is unreactive to supply and demand. That is what is happening today in the wool industry throughout the world. I applaud the minister's moves to allow some sort of statutory marketing mechanism to be left in place.

The other matter which must be dealt with here is the minister's moves to restrict half the flow of wool coming out of the stockpile by halfway through next year. It is my constantly reiterated contention that 20 per cent of the world's wool—some people would argue that it is 15 per cent—is coming out of the Australian stockpile. If you have the ability to cut off the source of 15 to 20 per cent of the world's wool then—as I clearly indicated happened with aluminium, coffee, oil, sugar in days past, and wool in days past—there will be a spectacular increase in the price of the product. So there should be a spectacular increase in the price of wool next year.

The only thing that I would urge the minister to ensure is that we indicate to our buyers a steely determination not to put our product on the world market at below the cost of production. In fairness to them, with the volatility of the product and the skyrocketing prices, we should be delivering something to them on that sort of situation.

In 1988, the prices went to 1,200c a kilo and then, because of the towering incompetence of the people in charge at the time, it collapsed to 350c a kilo. Nobody wants to work in that sort of business. Everyone would want to get out of it. These people are not gamblers, they are businessmen. That sort of volatility in the market requires people to be gamblers, not business people. So I think we owe our end users some sort of stability and some sort of reduction in the volatility that exists at the present moment.

If I knew that my competitor had to buy at the same price as I do, I would accept that situation. However, if I bought now and I did not know what the hell the price would be tomorrow, and I found that the competitor could undercut me by a huge amount, then that is not the sort of business that I would like to be in. If I wanted to become a professional gambler, I would spend my time down at the racetrack instead of in the business that I have addressed at various times throughout my life.

Finally, concerning the much maligned McEwen era in Australia, let us have a look at the scoreboard. Unemployment in 1972 was 1.9 per cent; the balance of payments was a surplus of $754 million; there were 2,600 bankruptcies as against 17,500 bankruptcies this year; and the value of the dollar was 384 Japanese yen to the Australian dollar whereas in 1997 it is 90 Japanese yen to the Australian dollar. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a matter of protocol. It is a while since I have been here. Do I refer to you as Mr Chair or‐
—My title is Deputy Speaker.
—I have spoken here many times before but not for quite a while. I had forgotten your title so I offer my apologies.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to begin by thanking members for their contributions to the debate in this place and senators for their contributions in the other place. I know that there are many people who feel very strongly about the industry and the current plight in which it finds itself. I know that there are many members and senators too who have first‐hand experience either through their own family involvements in the industry or more generally, as is my own case, in terms of their interaction with their constituents.

There is no doubt that the situation is a very serious one. I have made those observations before. After six years at least now of very low prices, often coupled with drought, many of our specialist wool growers in particular and the communities in which they live are on their financial knees. One can only express the very sincere hope that supply and demand will enter some new phase of equilibrium, a happier stage, in the very near future which will see a substantial improvement in prices. The flexibility that we are talking about before us in terms of the amendments to the Wool International Bill will hopefully allow for a better commercial outlook.

There is a point that arose out of the previous speaker's remarks, those of the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), that I think needs a brief mention. It was his hope as expressed, if I understand him correctly, that by cutting in half the amount of wool that Wool International will place on the markets, the price of wool would respond strongly to that reduction in supply. It needs to be clearly recognised that we have imposed in this legislation significant disciplines on the market. For example, there is a target date in 1998 that the debt be wound up and a legislated requirement that the stockpile should be wound up by the year 2000.

Those disciplines in broad terms mean that Wool International will still be required to dispose of, on average, 130,000 to 135,000 bales of wool per quarter. The reality is that if the price starts to rise strongly then more can be sold and we may be able to acquit the stockpile. One needs to remember that much of it is now not young any more and if anything the tendency towards purchasers wanting discounts in the future for that wool out of the stockpile is likely to increase. Therefore, it is desirable that it be, frankly, shifted.

The proposed amendments before us are the result of an extensive consultation process by the industry culminating in the August round table. On coming to this particular portfolio I found an industry that was deeply divided, deeply dispirited—and I think that is entirely understandable—and at odds with one another over whether the real problem was, on the one hand, the stockpile and/or its management, or, on the other hand, demand.

I came rapidly to the conclusion that we were not going to be able to effectively grapple with any of the problems, regardless of what one regarded as the most important and most pressing in terms of the need to find solutions, until we had established some industry unity and a deep awareness of the industry within its own ranks of both the desirability and the possibility of working together to find solutions and to ending the divisions. To this end we set about via the process of pulling together industry leaders, nationally and internationally, calling two ministerial round tables here in Canberra. We were seeking to establish that that unity was not only desirable but possible. I believe that we made tremendous progress.

The process between the two round tables of a very vigorous national debate over how to handle the stockpile was one of the most interesting that I have ever observed. I think it is fair to say that it started off as a fairly rocky period with some very strong views, often impossible to reconcile, being expressed by different players in the industry. As the debate rolled on several things happened, not the least of which, I suspect, was that many people became much more acutely aware of the real parameters within which we had to operate and gained a better understanding of the possibilities that were there and the challenges in front of us.

The result was that by the time we had the second round table the views had distilled out pretty clearly. I have to say that I think that is tremendously important and the significance of it should never be lost by the industry. Although it took us about five hours at that second round table to get through item No. 2 on the agenda—the future management of the stockpile—and we spent much less time than I would have liked on the other items on the agenda, we did sort this through very thoroughly. It took a long time, but we were able to agree on a very strong position of industry consensus. Many people made a great effort to secure that consensus; many moved considerably. That is the nature of reaching an agreed outcome.

I have to say that I absolutely and totally reject the allegation made by one industry that consensus was a process which, in this instance, arrived at a non‐decision. That is absolute nonsense. The industry needs to recognise that when they call for their views to be heard, and when people take very serious steps to ensure that that request is met and come up with a solution, that cannot be dismissed as mere consensus. It has to be recognised for what it is—genuine leadership in an industry that has been crying out for it.

I want to say that the recommendations that have been taken forward to the government, that have been accepted and are now about to become legislation are fully supported by the industry, including overseas customers who were a vital part of that round table process. I know that growers desperately need an injection of confidence. The international circus that arose when the Australian government flip‐flopped and belly‐ached all over the place in recent years and there was no certainty was something that I could not have allowed to happen again.

It was of vital importance that our international customers were drawn into this in a way which not only maintained but, if you like, secured or locked in their confidence in what we were doing in the future. That is what we set out to do and that is what I believe we have completed. I say to wool growers that it is very important that that be recognised. It is an extremely significant development.

The government is fully committed to the implementation of the round table outcomes, as shown by these amendments to the legislation. There has been wide debate on how they might best be used to maximise the value of the industry for hard‐pressed wool growers. I am delighted to note that the industry is insistent upon taking control of that debate itself. I think that is a very healthy thing and makes me feel extremely comfortable about withdrawing government involvement in an area where the government no longer needs to involve itself.

In terms of these amendments, there has been full consultation and, to date, bipartisan support. I do express my appreciation of that. I did so in the main chamber a little while ago and I do so again today. As I was able to extend a degree of bipartisan support to the then minister for primary industries in 1993 and as he was kind enough then to express his gratitude to me, I do so again in this instance. It is my view that it is very important that we now provide Wool International with full commercial flexibility in selling the stockpile to enable benefits to the industry to be maximised.

It is also the case, as I have just touched on, that the government is signalling through these amendments its intention to continue to withdraw from the industry in those areas which are not matters for government involvement. The fact of the matter is, that for all the criticism now levelled at the fixed release schedule, it wound back the debt to the point where it is now below $1 billion dollars—a vastly healthier situation than the one which we once faced. The stockpile is now down to below two million bales and this gives us the flexibility to be able to address other urgent priorities; namely, of course, in this instance, trying to provide relief to growers in terms of the price they receive for their fresh product.

I express my confidence that the industry is ready and able to provide its own leadership. Again, I touched on that a moment ago. I want to elaborate slightly and I just want to say a couple of things. It concerns me that there has been something of a tendency to confuse what has to be seen, in any objective analysis, as courage and genuine desire on the part of some of the industry's leadership to help, to make a difference, to secure the future; that that is sometimes confused with—misrepresented as—a refusal to listen, or a lack of understanding, or an inability to represent grassroots concerns and desires.

I think that is largely the end of it as a process of the round table. There is still a bit of mopping up to do and I hope that mopping up takes place. Unity is important; and recognising that there are people out there fighting for the industry, when they have other options that they could turn to, is very important too. As I said recently at a rather, if you like, interesting growers meeting, it needs to be recognised that people like Dick Warburton are genuinely trying to secure a more modern industry and that that commitment arises out of their real belief that change can bring better results for growers. And sometimes I think it is a little easy to overlook that.

There have been a lot of criticisms levelled, too, at growers' representatives. I really think that it is time that people got behind those representatives of their industry who are plainly trying to advance the causes and the interests of growers, and who are sometimes unfairly accused of not listening.

I make reference, on the way through, to the intelligent and understanding leadership of Rob Thirkell‐Johnston and Wool Council. It has not been easy for them, and it is altogether too easy to say that they are old guard, or not representative of the industry, or what have you. The bulk of them are practising wool growers. They have as much of an interest in sorting this through as anybody else does. And they are as frustrated by the problems of the industry as anybody else is in those industries.

In terms of the government's continuing involvement, there are some vitally important areas where we will continue to be involved and where, frankly, I think we can do more than has been done in the past. One obvious one is in creating the right broad economic environment for wool growers to operate in. Getting interest rates down is vitally important for growers with big debts, and there are too many of them. And, of course, since coming to power, we have seen a one per cent reduction, in broad terms, in interest rates and I sincerely hope that that is all passed on to wool growers. Across the Australian rural community it is worth around $200 million—quite a bit of money. Wool growers will experience some relief from that. There is more to be done and the government is determined to push ahead.

Industrial relations reform is important.
