It is often forgotten that Professor Garnaut identified savings to the average wool grower of some thousands of dollars through better transport, handling and storage facilities—and waterfront, of course—which usually centres on greater efficiencies, which are dependent upon a more co‐operative industrial relations environment.

Then, of course, there are questions such as market access and market negotiations which are very important, as is research and development. In relation to market access, the Mexican example that I referred to in the House the other day, whereby we provide wool tops and expertise as an input to the process to the Mexicans without tariffs getting in the way—they value add and re‐export under NAFTA without tariffs again into North America—is the very model of the sort of thing that we need to be looking for in the future; the very model of the sort of thing that governments in general, and ministers in particular, can help drive to the advancement of the industry in general terms.

Another proposal that arises out of the desire of industry leaders to, in practical terms, meet their responsibility under the 1993 act to develop a more modern industry with forward trading and so forth is the joint venture. This initially surfaced as the proposal known as Wool International Holdings. It has evolved into something that is quite different. Maybe that is partly as a result of the very tight parameters that I put in front of the industry leadership when I became minister about what would be acceptable and what would not.

Leaving that aside, an information paper is now being prepared on the proposed joint venture between Wool International, Elders and Wesfarmers Dalgety. Again, there have been too many in the industry who have wanted to say, `You know, John, close this off, we don't want to know about it. It's our money, and they want to put in $24 million of our money and we don't want you to put it in.' I have had some very strong representations. My response has been to say that we have got to explore every avenue in this industry that might offer something better for growers, that might offer better prices, reduced costs. It would be irresponsible of me as minister to close off that door before we have looked at it properly, fairly and objectively.

What we have before us is a situation where this information paper is being prepared. In the meantime, the prospective partners are actively consulting with growers and other industry sectors, and there will be plenty of time and opportunity for comment on the proposal by the industry. I have made it quite plain that the proposal must demonstrate broad industry support prior to my considering it for approval. It must also, of course, comply with competition policies.

We as a government are not interested in something that reduces competition to the cost of wool growers. We want to increase competition; we want better results out of people vying to offer better services at reduced cost; and we want better returns based on more effective marketing, handling and storage.

I note very strongly here that the great concern of some growers that Wool International wanted to use $24 million of their money out of section 51 funds on a trial program has now been addressed by the reality that Wool International is no longer seeking to use that money. Instead, it expects to fund its share of the partnership through a privatisation offer. I think that that dramatically alters the parameters of the debate. Quite frankly, it confirms my instinct that it was appropriate to hold the door open on this option and continue to explore it.

My department, in conjunction with Wool International and the Wool Council, is looking at related issues, including that of how to enable trading in the future equity of Wool International. Now the latter would be to enable early access to cash for growers. Remember that, in 1993, we were worried about whether we would ever make enough money out of the sale of the stockpile to cover the debt. Now we are looking at a substantial equity for growers, likely to be somewhere of the order of $2 to $2.50 return for every dollar in tax they have paid—do not quote me directly on that but I think those are the broad parameters. We are looking for ways to give growers early access to that through some system of trading of rights or trading of equity, and the idea would be to give growers as early a relief as possible.

We, as a government, together with industry leadership, want to cooperate with anything that will help hard‐pressed growers experience some relief in the current very difficult circumstances. Let me note that those who have concerns about Wool International being some sort of self‐perpetuating dynasty can be reassured by the simple reassurance that it is our very strong view that Wool International should be liquidated, and I think it is broadly accepted that is what will happen. It is our intention to wind it up when it has completed its task.

In conclusion, these amendments are the fruits of a comprehensive consultative process. They enjoy the enthusiastic support of the great majority in the wool industry, both here and overseas. I can tell you that the nature of the contacts in my office—correspondence received, telephone calls and so forth—has changed dramatically since the round table, something that I certainly want to see continue. I have been very pleased to have played a part in this process by providing the industry with a round table forum which was able to deliver such a high level of agreement.

This process, as I have said before, has demonstrated that all sectors of the wool industry can unite to come up with sensible, considered positions for the good of the whole industry in the longer term. It is important for us all now to focus on the very important priorities of how to encourage demand for wool and to increase our industry's efficiency and competitiveness with other natural and synthetic fibres on wool markets.

The government will remain ready to work closely with the industry to do whatever it can to improve access, to develop markets for wool internationally, and to pursue genuine reform in the domestic arena to improve the competitiveness and the bottom line outcome for Australia's wool growers, to whom I have a very deep personal commitment and to whom many people in this place share a deep commitment. The government is, in broad terms, fully cognisant of their current difficulties and the problems that will confront those communities if we do not turn the fortunes of the industry around very soon.

There are many areas in Australia where, frankly, the only option is to grow wool. So it is not just the wool growers in those areas who are affected, who are going to be wiped out if we cannot turn this great industry around, it will be the communities that back them up and service them as well. This is, in my view, a national priority. It is important to us economically; it is important to us socially. We really have to do everything we can. But it is great, I think, that the industry is now in a very strong position to take forward those things which belong to it, to take hold of those areas of leadership that are most appropriately the industry's, at the same time as we as the government fulfil enthusiastically and with vigour our responsibility to help in those areas of research and development, broad economic reform and market access and negotiations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 November, on motion by Mr Andrews:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Dondas moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"the House declines to give the Bill a second reading as it is of the opinion that to do so would be inappropriate given the conventions of self government, the judicial finding that voluntary euthanasia is a matter within the legislative and executive powers of the self governing Northern Territory and that such legislation would be within the capacity of the States and other self governing Territories of Australia".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was interrupted yesterday by a division and the subsequent adjournment of the Main Committee in its debate on the Euthanasia Laws Amendment Bill 1996, I was very keenly impressing upon all and sundry that I do understand that, despite the improvements in the standards of our palliative care, despite advances in the technology in that area, there are those in our community who suffer unacceptable pain for unacceptably long periods of time. It does not sit easily with me that my decision to support the private member's bill will deny some of those people the right to access the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act.

SPEECH.PARA: My position is not one I have taken lightly. Members of parliament have been inundated with information from various interest groups seeking to put their case in the last few months, and I have made the most of every opportunity to listen to them and have taken every opportunity to better educate myself on this issue. I also attended a seminar organised by the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) and the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), at which a number of pro‐euthanasia speakers addressed the gathering, including Professor Peter Baume, who is the Professor of Community Medicine at one of the large Sydney universities and also a former federal minister for health; Dr Roger Hunt, who is a senior consultant in palliative care; and Dr Roger Marr, from the John Hopkins University in the United States of America. And still I remain far from an expert on euthanasia and all the legal questions that go with it.

There are probably hundreds of people in my electorate who have a better understanding of euthanasia and palliative care and related issues than I do. No doubt there are thousands in my electorate who have had more experience with the terminally ill and the pain they suffer than I have. I thank the dozens of constituents who have written to me or contacted me by phone to express their views, often quite passionately. Many of them were making an effort to write to a politician for the very first time. Few of the written presentations were fancy but rather they were usually handwritten notes taken down, I feel, very soon after reading a newspaper article on the subject or hearing some television coverage of the subject or maybe talking to a friend in the street about the issue. It really is an issue that sparks emotion within most Australians.

But nothing I have read, no‐one I have talked to and nothing I have seen has been able to quell my concern that, once you move to legalise the intentional taking of another's life, you open a Pandora's box. It is not possible for a piece of legislation to govern adequately all the situations which sufferers and their families find themselves in. Those who support euthanasia say that people should have a choice. I agree. Indeed, I could not agree more. My fear is that, once euthanasia becomes an option, they will feel that they have no choice.

I am most concerned that people who have become a burden on their family and their friends will feel pressure, or even feel obliged, to choose the euthanasia option rather than continue to put their family and their friends through their own pain and suffering. The reality is that it is possible that family members with an unhealthy financial interest in a relative's demise could themselves put pressure on a patient to end his or her life.

When I raised my concerns with those who addressed the seminar here in Parliament House I was told, `We believe that in most cases that will not occur.' Mr Deputy Speaker, I believe that the overwhelming majority of Australians will agree with me when I say that `most of the time' is simply not good enough.

It is also possible, at least in my view, that, if future funding arrangements made it tempting, unscrupulous private nursing home operators could place pressure upon highly dependent patients to take the euthanasia option. I think questions as simple as `Do you realise what a burden you are now on your family?', placed at the right time—at a time when people suffering pain are quite emotional—could instil in them a feeling of obligation to request the euthanasia option.

To many Australians, euthanasia does seem a simple issue. To many it seems appropriate that people who are suffering unacceptable pain and who have been given no chance of survival should have a choice to end their suffering. But they do, effectively, have a choice now, Mr Deputy Speaker. The withdrawal of medical treatment which is sustaining a patient's life, including an intravenous drip or a respirator, is not illegal and occurs all the time. Similarly, doctors have a duty to provide whatever treatment a patient needs to ease their pain and suffering. This may mean increasing doses of morphine or other sedatives, even if this action in some way contributes to the patient's death. This is not euthanasia. These are simply acts which allow nature to take its course. By contrast, euthanasia is the use of a substance designed to bring about death intentionally. There is a very big difference.

Mr Deputy Speaker, once we allow euthanasia to become acceptable, what sort of commitment can we expect from governments in the area of funding of palliative care? How keen will the large pharmaceutical and research companies be to invest in research and development in the area of palliative care once the demand for their product starts to drop off because of the availability of euthanasia? How much do they now spend seeking an answer to diseases like malaria which usually are only prominent in Third World countries, where there just is not the money to purchase the drugs? Where will this leave those who have the desire to fight on, those who seek help, those who want to live, those who want to survive? Are we to become a society that has decided it is cheaper and easier to force people to press `yes'?

I turn now to the issue of state and territory rights. I note the presence of the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas), who is very concerned about this issue. It concerns me that the bill seeks to override the will of a democratically elected legislature. However, I have to ask myself what is more important: the question of territory rights or the right of every person to be given a chance to live?

We have legislatures to sustain life, to maximise the quality of life and to control those who seek to deny people those rights. For me, the choice between territory rights and life itself will always be very simple. To those who say, `This is a matter only for Territorians,' I simply say that there is such a thing as a one‐way ticket to the Northern Territory. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nairn, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking in this debate as I believe it is important that the people of Eden‐Monaro know exactly why I will not be supporting the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. Firstly, I want to say that I have never advocated nor campaigned for or against the introduction of voluntary euthanasia. It is not a matter I have personally felt strongly about.

SPEECH.PARA: I do, however, have absolute respect for those parties who embrace a strong view on one or other side of this issue, but I do not believe this bill is the forum for a national debate on voluntary euthanasia. This bill does not address the issue of voluntary euthanasia at a national level. This might be the national parliament, but any or all of the six states of Australia could pass voluntary euthanasia legislation tomorrow, and this bill would have absolutely no effect on it. In fact, I read in today's newspapers that a euthanasia bill was being introduced in the South Australian parliament only yesterday. How can this be a debate about voluntary euthanasia for Australia?
In his second reading speech, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) said:

BREAK.PARA: If the parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia cannot resolve a matter that goes to the life and death of its citizens, then what is the purpose of the parliament?

If the honourable member for Menzies believes that that is what he is doing with this bill, then I would suggest that he does not understand his own bill and he does not understand the Australian constitution. The states could legislate tomorrow on euthanasia and this bill would have no effect at all.

If the objective of the honourable member for Menzies and other members supporting this bill is to prevent voluntary euthanasia legislation nationwide, then they should be attacking it in an entirely different way. Quite frankly, I wish they would, because out there in the electorate the perception is that this bill is the definitive statement on whether there can or cannot ever be voluntary euthanasia across Australia. Legally and constitutionally, that clearly is not the case.

What this bill is seeking to do is to amend the Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act 1978, the Australian Capital Territory (Self‐Government) Act 1988 and the Norfolk Island Act 1979. It is not a bill to directly wipe out the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act; it is a bill to retrospectively say that the Northern Territory did not have the right to make that law.

Just think clearly about that for a moment, because I am not confident that everyone understands that, even some honourable members. Certainly, the majority of the electorate does not understand that. If all honourable members do understand that this bill will amend the self‐government acts of the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory, I doubt that many of them really understand the background and workings of those acts. Some might think it is irrelevant, but I would argue otherwise, and I will explain the importance of it in relation to this bill.

As it is primarily the Northern Territory that is under attack by this bill, I will use it to demonstrate my point—plus I have had some experience in that part of Australia. Some people believe my opposition to this bill is based purely on the fact that I once lived in the Northern Territory for a few years of my career. That is not the case.

I point out to those people that I was born, bred and educated in Sydney, I lived and worked in England for a year, I lived and worked close to the Swiss border in France for nearly two years, and I have lived in another regional and rural part of New South Wales as well as where I currently live in Queanbeyan. I am uniquely placed because, having lived in the Northern Territory for a number of years, I can at least understand their position and can rationalise the issues.

When the Commonwealth government granted self‐government to the Northern Territory in 1978, they gave to the Northern Territory parliament power to make laws over all matters, except four specific areas. Those four specific areas were: industrial relations, uranium mining, Aboriginal land rights and control over Uluru and Kakadu national parks. All other matters were the domain of the Northern Territory parliament. The Commonwealth, however, also included a safeguard clause. That safeguard was that the Commonwealth could reject any law within six months of the Northern Territory passing the law. That safeguard was not taken up by the previous federal government with respect to the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. It was not taken up even in the face of strong representations by the anti‐euthanasia lobby.

Many of the honourable members now supporting this amendment to the self‐government act were in the parliament at the time, but they were silent on the issue. Many of the honourable members now supporting this amendment to the self‐government act were part of the government at the time, but they chose not to utilise the specific provision that the Commonwealth had. So why have they changed their minds now? I do not know, but perhaps one of those members might explain why when they debate this bill.

I could, however, speculate and say that the general consensus at the time was that the Northern Territory had always acted responsibly since 1978 in the formulation of their laws, and therefore it was wrong to interfere. And they have acted responsibly. Never, since 1978, has the Commonwealth felt the need to utilise the `safeguard' clause, let alone change the self‐government act to take more powers away. They have not felt the need because the Northern Territory parliament has acted responsibly and in line with the wishes of the people they represent. If they had not, the people would have changed the government. But they have not changed the government since self‐government in 1978. In fact, they have not changed it since 1974 when the Legislative Assembly was first elected.

So surely the proper test in considering this bill should be to look closely at the performance of the Northern Territory parliament since 1978. Surely that is a reasonable thing to do before we throw ourselves headlong into amending the self‐government act. Any reasonable analysis of their performance will result in a pretty good report card.

They have been responsible, they have been democratic, they have governed for all. After 18 years of self‐government, the Northern Territory has developed into a vibrant economy and, in many areas, has become the envy of other parts of Australia. They have not only been responsible, they have also led the nation in some critical areas. For example, firearms legislation in the Northern Territory prior to the Port Arthur massacre was accepted as being the second toughest in Australia.

The Northern Territory has been the accepted leader in anti‐alcohol abuse programs. Through their living with alcohol program, over a five‐year period alcohol statistics have changed dramatically. For instance, light beer sales have gone from one per cent of the market to 28 per cent. There has been a 26 per cent reduction in the number of alcohol related road fatalities and in road accidents overall. This is a program that has been picked up elsewhere in Australia.

Another example is the Northern Territory's recognition of Aboriginal customary law in the Northern Territory legal system. This progressive model is being followed and considered by other jurisdictions. I could provide many other examples of progressive, landmark legislation in the legal and social justice areas which are being hailed nationally. My purpose in providing this information is to indicate that the legislature of the Northern Territory has acted responsibly. Its parliament has followed the democratic process in the passing of all of its legislation. The topical act in question, the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, was no different.

The Commonwealth does not have the power to reject that piece of legislation directly. The time in which the Commonwealth did have that power has passed. So now the only way to do it is by amendment to the self‐government act. Given the history, given the detail of what has occurred, given the proper procedures that the Northern Territory parliament has followed, I believe it would be the height of arrogance for us to now intervene in another parliament.

My resolve not to support the bill before us is strengthened by the fact that this bill does not address euthanasia at a national level. As I said earlier, any state could introduce legislation tomorrow and this bill does nothing to prevent it. The only way for the federal parliament to have control of this issue is by way of referendum. After receiving volumes of correspondence and representations, I fully understand that there are very strong personal views at both ends of the euthanasia debate. The two extremes are insisting I represent those views. How can one person represent both views? One person cannot.

If we are ever to address this nationally—and I repeat that this bill does not—it has to be given to the people. I do not support referenda willy‐nilly, but on this intensely personal issue it could be the only fair way. I reject this bill as it is an unfair attack on a democratic parliament, and it does not address voluntary euthanasia nationally. Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to express my appreciation to the many people who have spoken to me or taken the trouble to write to me or telephone me to let me know their views on Kevin Andrews's private member's bill, the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. I thank also those who let me know their views on the Northern Territory's legislation on euthanasia, as well as their reasons for opposing or supporting euthanasia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a credit to this parliament that this important debate is taking place in a manner that affords respect to the views expressed by each member. It should not be surprising that a bill like this which seeks to deal with the very way our society values life should attract the support of members of the government and the opposition. This is not to question the sincerity or the good intentions of those from all parties who have chosen to oppose the Kevin Andrews bill.

The only sour note is the decision of the government to refuse to allow all but six speakers in this debate to speak in the House of Representatives chamber. The rest of us have been relegated to this small committee room which has only limited space for members of the public, or members of parliament for that matter. The decision also denies radio listeners around the country an opportunity to listen to one of the few debates where the debate may influence the outcome and where the outcome is unknown. A debate about whether euthanasia should be allowed to be practised in Australia is important enough for the House of Representatives chamber, not `sideshow alley', as this room has been affectionately and accurately described.

Turning to the Kevin Andrews bill, let me begin by addressing the constitutional questions. No‐one questions that the federal parliament retains the legal right to make laws for the territories. Granting self-government to the ACT or the Northern Territory or Norfolk Island does not prevent the national parliament from setting the laws of the territories. For example, if one of the territory assemblies enacted a law to allow capital punishment in that territory then I believe the national parliament would have the right, if not the obligation, to overrule that law.

For the record, I would have preferred that the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly would never have passed its legislation legalising euthanasia in that territory, and having been passed I would have preferred that the Northern Territory's euthanasia legislation should have been repealed by the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly.

It is clear that there are some members of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly who are not prepared to vote to repeal this bill, even though they personally may be opposed to euthanasia. There has been some recent speculation that they would prefer that the High Court strike the legislation down. As I said, my preference would be for the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly to repeal the bill but if it does not have the votes or the courage to repeal the law, then it is my view that this parliament has the right to intervene.

One of the central core views of our society is the high value we place on life. We can see it in the joy of birth, we can see it in the pain we feel when someone close to us dies, we can see it in the public anger which can erupt after a murder and the severe penalties which our society imposes on those who commit murder. We can see it in the lengths our community will go to to save a life, whether it be the resources we devote to trying to save someone who is critically injured or the many acts of valour performed by people who place their own lives at risk to try to save the life of another. Euthanasia undermines this central element of our humanity.

We need to distinguish euthanasia from other ethical and legal ways of providing palliative care to people with terminal illnesses. Patients have the right to refuse treatments that prolong suffering. Families and doctors can withhold or discontinue life‐prolonging treatments. For example, if a person's brain functions have ceased but that person is being kept alive by a machine or intrusive procedures, it is legal to allow that person to die by turning off the machine. The South Australian parliament has codified the common law right of a doctor to legally provide pain relief, even in circumstances where providing medication to relieve pain may risk shortening life. Clearly, the intention of a doctor in those circumstances is to relieve the suffering and not to put an end to life.

I would like to quote from the second reading of the Consent to Medical Treatment and Palliative Care Bill in the South Australian Legislative Assembly on 26 November 1992 when Mr Martyn Evans, now the honourable member for Bonython, made the following remarks in introducing the bill:

What the Bill does seek to ensure is that a medical practitioner will not incur liability by administering a medical procedure for the relief of pain or distress if he or she acts with the appropriate consent, in good faith and without negligence, and in accordance with proper standards of palliative care, even though an incidental and unintended effect of the treatment is to hasten the death of the patient.
I would also like to quote an extract from the catechism of the Catholic Church which has been sent to me by one of my constituents. It says:

2279 Even if death is thought imminent, the ordinary care owed to a sick person cannot be legitimately interrupted. The use of painkillers to alleviate the sufferings of the dying, even at the risk of shortening their days, can be morally in conformity with human dignity if death is not willed as either an end or a means, but only foreseen and tolerated as inevitable. Palliative care is a special form of disinterested charity. As such it should be encouraged.

Euthanasia is very different. The Northern Territory legislation allows a doctor to terminate a patient's life by giving him a lethal injection. The intention is clearly to end life. Once society crosses this threshold it is very difficult to know when to stop.

In future, will a doctor be allowed to terminate the life of a young person if they are believed to have a terminal illness? What about a person of any age who wishes to commit suicide? Or what about a person who suffers from disability? There was an example in one of the papers this morning of a quadriplegic with an incurable illness, but not a terminal disease. How will we ensure that elderly people do not feel under pressure or under some unstated obligation to consider euthanasia because of the impact of the cost of hospital treatment or the cost of aged care on their family's assets or their children's inheritance? For all these reasons I will be voting in favour of Kevin Andrews's bill to overturn the Northern Territory's euthanasia legislation.

Apart from striking down this legislation, something positive can flow from this debate. These days most Australians have access to good quality palliative care. Unfortunately, some other regions—including the Northern Territory—need more resources to ensure every Australian has access to this essential care if we or a member of our family or community are unlucky enough to need it.

The recent budget regrettably broadbanded, then reduced by 10 per cent, federal funding for palliative care and some other health payments to the states and territories. I accept that no government has access to unlimited resources. But it is hard to think of a more worthy cause than to extend a helping hand to a person who has a terminal illness. And it is hard to think of a more worthy cause than to extend that helping hand to that person's family and friends whose only wish is to ensure that he or she can die with dignity.
Debate (on motion by Mr Charles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the detailed environmental surveys of contaminated sites at the Australian National Islington workshops at Kilburn, SA, referred to in the Auditor‐General's report No. 31 of 1995‐96, been completed; if so, what were the findings; if not, when will they be completed.

(2) Are these sites (a) within Australian National's property portfolio, other than the Islington workshops, or (b) elsewhere for which he has portfolio responsibility which have been used for dumping foundry waste, acids, alkalis, scrap metal, arsenic, cadmium, chromium, copper, nickel, lead, zinc or asbestos; if so, so in each case, (i) where is the site located, (ii) what is the nature of the dumping, (iii) what surveys have been conducted, (iv) what were the findings, (v) what measures have been proposed to manage, contain or remove the contaminants and (vi) what is the estimated cost of each proposal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The site referred to in the Auditor‐General's report No. 31 is adjacent to, and not part of, Australian National's (AN) Islington workshop. This land is still owned by AN but has been declared surplus to AN's requirements and AN has sought to return it to SA as it is required to do under the SA Transfer Agreement. The decontamination of this site was the subject of a detailed report by the CSIRO dated 12 January 1996. A copy of the report has been provided to the Honourable Member's office.

Separately, AN has advised that an environmental compliance audit for the Islington workshops site has been completed. Following the audit, AN engaged a panel of environmental consultants to conduct further investigations. This work is expected to commence soon.

(2)(a) AN engaged consultants Rust PPK to undertake a detailed environmental audit of its property portfolio. The report revealed contamination typical of railway activity at 106 sites includ ing the presence of contaminants such as hydrocarbons, heavy metals, pesticides and asbestos. However, these sites are located at various properties throughout AN's railway network, not at the Islington workshops.
(2)(b) The following information refers to the properties of other bodies within the portfolio.

The Australian National Line does not have property which has been used for dumping foundry waste, acids, alkalis, scrap metal, arsenic, cadmium, copper, nickel, lead, zinc or asbestos. There is, however, some low‐level incidental contamination at sites due to general industrial use.

On the Australian Maritime Safety Authority's (AMSA) establishment a significant property portfolio associated with the operation of lighthouses was transferred from the Commonwealth. These facilities had been operated at various times by State and Commonwealth agencies and the extent of contamination, if any, on these sites is not known.

There is some possibility of low level contamination at lighthouse sites due to the use of petroleum fuels, asbestos building material, lead/acid or zinc/acid batteries, and mercury from optical mechanism bearings.

AMSA is in the process of commissioning contamination audits, for which results are not yet available, at the following lighthouse sites to establish the extent of any contamination associated with the sites earlier use as manned lighthouses.
Cape Byron Booby Island
Green Cape Bustard Head
Norah Head Cape Capricorn
Point Stephens Cape Cleveland
Smoky Cape Cape Moreton
Sugarloaf Point Sandy Cape

AMSA is currently transferring the majority of former manned lightstations to the various State governments. Conditions of the transfer are generally that AMSA receives a `nil' value, with the State accepting any liability for any contamination that may have been associated with the operation of the earlier lighthouse technology.
The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has developed a Contaminated Sites Register thereby maintaining the current but constantly changing status of contaminated sites.
The register provides details on the specific contaminants referred to in the question—arsenic, cadmium, chromium, copper, nickel, lead, zinc, and asbestos.

The register does not include the broad terms of foundry waste, scrap metal, acids and alkalis, which could be found on any airport or large tract of land that has or is being used for commercial/industrial activity.
The attached matrix identifies:

PARA.TAB: FAC airports that have contaminated sites listed on the register (with a tick) and are undergoing remediation. The matrix also confirms that background data is held for each, consistent with questions (2)(b)(i) through to 2(b)(v). Cost of

ANSWER.PARA: remediation 2(b)(vi) is an airport by airport responsibility and not maintained in the register.

PARA.TAB: FAC airports that do not currently have contaminated sites as defined by the register (with a cross).

ANSWER.PARA: The background data referred to above is extensive and not easily provided in response to the questions posed.
In addition, developing further definition, instigating investigation and producing reports on foundry waste and scrap metal would put excessive pressure on the FAC at this time.

It should be noted that the FAC has a strict environmental regime in place at its airports, and the new Airports Act 1996 and the regulations which are currently being developed, will impose strict environmental controls at all Federal airports being leased by private operators.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the incidence of bird strikes at Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport during the period from 1 January 1991 to 31 December 1995.
(2) What measures will be adopted by the Federal Airports Corporation in response to the development of wetlands in the vicinity of Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport and at Towra Point near Kurnell.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During the period from 1 January 1991 to 31 December 1995 a total of 278 occurrences were reported to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation involving bird strike at Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport.
Of these occurrences six resulted in minor damage to the aircraft.
(2) The Federal Airports Corporation has advised that Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport will continue to manage the wetlands under its control in accordance with the Botany Wetlands Management Plan.
The Federal Airports Corporation has advised that it is not involved in the development of Towra Point near Kurnell.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 9 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What estimate has been made of the additional vehicular transport that will converge on Sydney in the period immediately preceding, during and immediately after the Sydney Olympic Games.

(2) What discussions has his Department had with the NSW Department of Road Transport about the ability of the NSW road system, and Sydney in particular, to handle the increased volume of vehicular traffic.
(3) What consideration is being given by his Department or any agency for which he is responsible to assist NSW cope with traffic problems resulting from the Sydney Olympic Games.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: (1) The Olympic bid materials made it clear that the NSW Government considered that Sydney land transport infrastructure in place now, and planned to be in place by 2000, would be adequate to meet demand generated by the Olympics.

(2) The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has had discussions with the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority (RTA) regarding ground access links serving Sydney Airport for the Olympic period and beyond. The FAC has also provided inputs to the RTA on the need for adequate connecting roads between the airport and the proposed Eastern Distributor and the M5 East.

(3) The FAC has approved works estimated to cost $55 million for road and car park improvements at the Domestic and International Terminals at Sydney Airport. Further road works within the airport boundary are under consideration for construction by the year 2000. Planning mechanisms are in place to ensure adequate coordination of these works with those contemplated by the RTA.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Second Sydney Airport: Air Traffic Projections

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 9 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Do reports exist of studies on (a) air traffic projections for the Sydney region or (b) how the air traffic needs of conurbations similar to Sydney elsewhere in the world have been conducted; if not, on what basis did the Government decide to commit taxpayers' money to build a second Sydney airport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Yes.
Air traffic projections are produced by a number of organisations, including the Department of Transport and Regional Development.

During 1994 the then Department of Transport provided aircraft and passenger movement projections for the Sydney Basin to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure (HORSCOTI) as part of the `Inquiry into the Sydney 2000 Olympics'. In July 1995, the Department provided similar projections to the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise (SSCAN), and to the Sydney Airport Consultative Committee (SACCC).
The projections are currently being updated to reflect the latest available statistical information and will be released in the near future.
(b) Yes.

A significant body of research exists on the development and management of existing multi‐airport systems in a variety of cities throughout the world. This research will be drawn on in the development of the Environmental Impact Statement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 10 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the construction of a second Sydney airport at Holsworthy affect the navigational routes of planes utilising Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport (KSA); if so, will it necessitate a review of the long term operating plan for KSA being devised by the Sydney Air Traffic Management Task Force which is due to report to him on or about 16 December 1996.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Possible effects of a second major airport at either Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy on the navigational routes of planes using KSA will be considered in the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) currently being prepared for the proposed airport development. Airservices Australia is working with the EIS consultants on this issue and is taking into account potential effects on KSA flight paths from the proposed second Sydney airport.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 10 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the Department of Foreign Affairs threatened to issue a Ministerial Certificate in the name of the Minister for Foreign Affairs to prevent the release of 122 pages of Australian Security Intelligence Organization (ASIO) files on the late Bruce Joseph Milliss, in a case brought by Mr Milliss's son before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, on the grounds, inter alia, that their release might jeopardise ASIO's method of operation.

(2) Had ASIO intercepted telephone calls to and from the Soviet Embassy and recorded conversations between Mr Milliss and the Soviet Trade Attache, as well as similar conversations with the Polish Consulate in Sydney; if so, is the interception and recording of telephone conversations to and from foreign Embassies and High Commissions a violation of Australia's obligations under international law and Australian law.
(3) Have the diplomatic privileges of any other countries been offended by the interception of communications to or from their embassies in Australia.
(4) Will he give an assurance that ASIO no longer engages in such practices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Honourable member has directed the same question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Minister for Foreign Affairs is better able to answer a question concerning actions by officers of his Department.

(2)-(4) It has been the policy of successive Australian governments not to comment on operational intelligence matters as to do otherwise might prejudice national security. I intend to maintain that policy. I am advised that documents have been released to Mr Milliss's son. I do not intend to comment on what the documents in question might or might not reveal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Taxation Office in Northbridge, WA, to be re‐located to Cannington.
(2) Is this relocation convenient for WA taxpayers.
(3) Is rental at Cannington in the region of $325 per square metre while at Northbridge it is $87 per square metre.
(4) What savings will result from the relocation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is currently considering proposals involving making savings in accommodation and administration expenses by implementing best practice standard. The benefits gained from improvements will be used for additional staff and support for operation of the Taxation System for the Australian community.
In relation to buildings occupied in Western Australia, the ATO proposes to actively market both buildings to determine which accommodation to retain.

(2) The Commissioner advises that the ATO has no plans to reduce services to taxpayers. The ATO recognises the need for new work practices, greater operational efficiency and increased use of technology in continuing to provide a high level of services to taxpayers. For example, the ATO plans to make greater use of electronic communication in a number of ways, and this could provide significant benefits to the business community in dealing with the ATO. It may mean some services are delivered differently in future, but the ATO remains committed to providing a high level of service to taxpayers.
(3) The rental at Cannington is within the region of $325 per square metre and at Northbridge it is of a higher order.

(4) Subject to the outcome of further investigations and consultation the ATO anticipates a reduction in overheads, through consolidating staff numbers and flexible work patterns. This reduction will allow investment in new technology and compliance improvement initiatives which will assist in putting more people into jobs dealing directly with the community.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 19 September 1996:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Are emission standards for Australian‐made motor vehicles lower than those for vehicles made in the USA; if so, what are the comparative standards.

(2) Have exported motor components made to Australian standards been rejected by the USA; if so, (a) are those components now being made to higher standards and (b) why are the higher standards not adopted in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The current emission limits in Australia are generally less stringent than those in the US. New standards which start to take effect in Australia from 1 January 1997 are equivalent to those standards which applied in the US until the end of 1993.

The emission limits for passenger cars are listed in the table below, which shows Australia's current standards [ADR37/00], the standards which will start to come into effect in Australia from the beginning of next year [ADR37/01] and the current standards in the US. These later Australian standards are already being reviewed to establish standards which would take effect early in the next century.
(1) To be phased in over 1/1/97—1/1/99.

(2) The US 1994‐6 standards also increase the "Full Useful Life" standards from the current period of 5yrs/80,000km to 10yrs/160,000km, while allowing some relaxation of emission limits after 5yr/80,000km.
(3) The US 1994‐6 standards require total hydrocarbons 0.26g/km, with the non‐methane hydrocarbons content being 0.15g/km.

(2) I am not aware of any Australian made vehicle components being exported to the US being rejected. Any company exporting a product needs to ensure that it meets the standards laid down in the receiving country, which may of course be different from those in Australia. Australia is supporting efforts towards the international harmonisation of vehicle standards so as to promote trade in vehicles and vehicle components.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Council for the Order of Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mr Latham

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 15 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 679 (Hansard , 9 October 1996, page 5065), are Admiral Sinclair's entitlements and enrolment as a member of the Council for the Order of Australia different to those arising from his appointment as Chair of the Council; if so, what are the details.
(2) What are the nature of transport-related costs the Government has agreed to pay Admiral Sinclair for his attendance at inter-State Council meetings.
(3) What home base has Admiral Sinclair nominated for the purpose of travelling allowance and transport-related costs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2)-(3) See my answer to part 2 of Parliamentary Question No 679. Meetings of the Council for the Order of Australia are held in Canberra and Admiral Sinclair attends these from his home near Newcastle, NSW. There are no other "inter-State" meetings of the Council for the Order of Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 16 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to claims that the Government's decision to alter access rules for Medicare Provider Numbers applied to general practitioners is likely to result annually in up to 40 WA medical students being unable to practice.
(2) Is it a fact that, unlike Sydney or Melbourne, there remain shortages of general practitioners in WA which will be exacerbated by alteration of the access rules.

(3) Is it also a fact that WA relies on its city based junior doctors to staff a highly successful locum support program for country doctors which has enabled doctor vacancies in all rural towns except Laverton to be filled and that these changes will put these regional medical services at risk.
(4) Will he ensure that WA is not disadvantaged by these changes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Claims that new medical practitioners in WA will be unable to practice medicine are without foundation. There is no reason why any medical practitioner who wishes to do so will be unable to practice medicine. The Budget measure limiting Medicare access for new medical practitioners will only affect a very small proportion of WA medical students. Most medical students will continue to gain access to training places offered by the RACGP and specialist colleges. The handful of new graduates not going on to post graduate training will be able to work in salaried positions such as those offered by public hospitals, government, the armed forces, pharmaceutical companies and academia. Available figures indicate that there are large numbers of vacancies in these areas.

(2) In January 1996 the Australian Medical Workforce Advisory Committee issued a report providing medical workforce benchmarks in respect of all medical disciplines including general practice. On page 21 of the report the Committee concluded that overall WA had an oversupply of 163 general practitioners (ie 13.9%). By comparison the oversupply in NSW and Victoria was 20.5% and 17.7% respectively. The fact that shortages remain in certain areas is a problem common to all states, including NSW and Victoria. These shortages are particularly common to rural areas and public hospitals and reflect the maldistribution of the medical workforce rather than an overall shortage.

(3) The rural locum support program operating in WA is heavily subsidised by Commonwealth Government funding. Funding for this program has continued in this year's Federal Budget. Furthermore funding for such services is likely to increase by virtue of $20m additional funding per annum being made available as part of the budget measure aimed at redressing the maldistribution of medical practitioners. In addition, I have recently announced that continued access to Medicare will be available to new doctors working for approved rural locum programs.

(4) It is difficult to envisage why any state would be disadvantaged by these changes—particularly as they are likely to result in a substantial improvement in the distribution of the medical workforce. Furthermore the provision of $20m pa to assist in the redistribution of the medical workforce is likely to produce substantial benefits for rural areas in all States including WA.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What means is available to locate and remove unexploded munitions in firing range areas.
(2) Has the technology in use improved as a result of the techniques and equipment utilised during the Gulf War in 1991; if so, what is the nature and effectiveness of the improvement.
(3) What cleansing rate of unexploded munitions, expressed as a percentage, can be achieved on firing ranges.
(4) What is the cost per hectare to remove munitions and how long does it take to clear a hectare.
(5) Does the cleansing process involve risk to personnel; if so, what is the level of risk.
(6) To what depth and surface impaction can it be guaranteed that unexploded munitions have been removed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are a number of technologies available for the detection of unexploded munitions, including magnetic resonance, magnetic flux, ground penetrating radar and infra red and thermal imaging. Once detected, unexploded munitions can be uncovered and destroyed or rendered safe using a variety of means, for example with explosives.

(2) Most clearance procedures used on the Gulf War battlefield dated from World War II. However, improvements are being effected for both battlefield and non‐operational clearance, mostly in relation to methods of detection. The combination of various technologies such as magnetic detection, radar and thermal imaging will result in higher probabilities of detection.

(3)‐(4) No definite rate of detection or clearance costs and timings can be provided as these depend on the type of munitions, how it was delivered, its size, the soil conditions and the detection and clearance equipment used. Commercial clearance companies will provide a cost for clearance of a particular area of land, dependent on the factors listed.

(5) There is always some level of risk to personnel in dealing with unexploded munitions. The risk is related to the type, size and condition of the munitions and the nature of the land. The level of competence of personnel involved in any operation is also a factor.
(6) The depth of clearance is dependent on the size of the munitions, soil type and other environmental factors, and the type of clearance equipment used.
